What is the purpose of the `lockunspent` command in Verus?

The `lockunspent` command is used to update the list of temporarily unspendable outputs in Verus. It allows you to temporarily lock or unlock specified transaction outputs, which affects whether they are chosen by automatic coin selection when spending VRSC.

### `lockunspent unlock [{"txid":"txid","vout":n},...]`
Updates list of temporarily unspendable outputs.
Temporarily lock (unlock=false) or unlock (unlock=true) specified transaction outputs.
A locked transaction output will not be chosen by automatic coin selection, when spending VRSC.
Locks are stored in memory only. Nodes start with zero locked outputs, and the locked output list is always cleared (by virtue of process exit) when a node stops or fails.
Also see the listunspent call#### Arguments:
1. unlock      (boolean, required) Whether to unlock (true) or lock (false) the specified transactions
2. "transactions" (string, required) A json array of objects. Each object the txid (string) vout (numeric)
```json
   [      (json array of json objects)
    {
     "txid":"id",  (string) The transaction id
     "vout": n     (numeric) The output number
    }
    ,...
   ]
```
#### Result:
true|false  (boolean) Whether the command was successful or notExamples:List the unspent transactions
```bash
> verus listunspent
```
Lock an unspent transaction
```bash
> verus lockunspent false "[{\"txid\":\"a08e6907dbbd3d809776dbfc5d82e371b764ed838b5655e72f463568df1aadf0\",\"vout\":1}]"
```
List the locked transactions
```bash
> verus listlockunspent
```
Unlock the transaction again
```bash
> verus lockunspent true "[{\"txid\":\"a08e6907dbbd3d809776dbfc5d82e371b764ed838b5655e72f463568df1aadf0\",\"vout\":1}]"
```
As a json rpc call
```bash
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "lockunspent", "params": [false, "[{\"txid\":\"a08e6907dbbd3d809776dbfc5d82e371b764ed838b5655e72f463568df1aadf0\",\"vout\":1}]"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```

How do I use the `lockunspent` command to lock an unspent transaction in Verus?

To lock an unspent transaction, you can use the `lockunspent` command with the following format:

```
verus lockunspent false "[{\"txid\":\"transaction_id\",\"vout\":output_number}]"
```

Replace `transaction_id` with the actual transaction ID and `output_number` with the output number of the transaction you want to lock.

### `lockunspent unlock [{"txid":"txid","vout":n},...]`

Temporarily lock (unlock=false) or unlock (unlock=true) specified transaction outputs.
A locked transaction output will not be chosen by automatic coin selection, when spending VRSC.
Locks are stored in memory only. Nodes start with zero locked outputs, and the locked output list is always cleared (by virtue of process exit) when a node stops or fails.
Also see the listunspent call#### Arguments:
1. unlock      (boolean, required) Whether to unlock (true) or lock (false) the specified transactions
2. "transactions" (string, required) A json array of objects. Each object the txid (string) vout (numeric)
```json
   [      (json array of json objects)
    {

    ,...
   ]
```

How do I list all the unspent transactions in Verus?

You can list all the unspent transactions in Verus using the `listunspent` command:

```
verus listunspent
```

How do I unlock a previously locked transaction in Verus?

To unlock a previously locked transaction, you can use the `lockunspent` command with the `unlock` parameter set to `true`:

```
verus lockunspent true "[{\"txid\":\"transaction_id\",\"vout\":output_number}]"
```

Replace `transaction_id` with the actual transaction ID and `output_number` with the output number of the transaction you want to unlock.

### `lockunspent unlock [{"txid":"txid","vout":n},...]`
Updates list of temporarily unspendable outputs.
Temporarily lock (unlock=false) or unlock (unlock=true) specified transaction outputs.
A locked transaction output will not be chosen by automatic coin selection, when spending VRSC.
Locks are stored in memory only. Nodes start with zero locked outputs, and the locked output list is always cleared (by virtue of process exit) when a node stops or fails.
Also see the listunspent call#### Arguments:
1. unlock      (boolean, required) Whether to unlock (true) or lock (false) the specified transactions
2. "transactions" (string, required) A json array of objects. Each object the txid (string) vout (numeric)
```json
   [      (json array of json objects)
    {
     "txid":"id",  (string) The transaction id

    }
    ,...
   ]
```
#### Result:

```bash
> verus listunspent
```
